bibl.title: Petitioner v. Defendant. Type of document
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: United States District Court Western District of Washington, Northern Division.
In the matter of the petition of Arthur B. Martin for a Writ of Habeas Corpus. } No. 2852 Return
To the Honorable Judge of the United States District Çourt for the Western District of Washington:

Comes now Henry M. White, United States Commissioner of Immigration at the port of Seattle, Washington, and makes this return to the writ of habeas corpus heretofore issued in the above entitled matter and produces in court the body of the said Arthur B. Martin, and alleges as follows:

I. He admits the following allegations of the petition: 1. That the petitioner was arrested June 23, 1910, charged with a violation of the Mann Act, and upon a trial being had was sentenced to five years in the federal penitentiary at McNeil island; which sentence petitioner has served.

2. That petitioner was discharged from the federal penitentary September 10, 1914, and taken into custody by a United States immigration inspector acting under respondent's orders, and since said date petitioner has been detained at the United States immigration station in Seattle awaiting deportation.

II. That the respondent denies the remaining allegations -1-
of the petition and specifically denies that petitioner was taken and detained illegally, and that petitioner is a citizen of the United States of America.
For a Further and Affirmative Return to said Writ the Said Henry M. White alleges:

I. 1. That petitioner is now in the custody of the United States immigration authorities under and by virtue of a warrant of deportation issued by the Department of Commerce and Labor, dated July 30, 1910, a copy of which is attached hereto as "Exhibit A", made a part hereof by reference.

2. That said warrant was issued under the authority of the Immigration Act of Feburary 20, 1907, as amended, charging the petitioner with being an alien person of the excluded class, and now entitled to be or remain in the United States, to-wit: That petitioner is an alien who imported, procurred and brought into the United States a prostitute, or a woman, or a girl, for the purpose of prostitution, or other immoral purposes; and that he entered without inspection. That the period of three years after his landing in the United States has not elapsed.

3. That the aforesaid warrant was served upon petitioner immediately upon his discharge form the federal penitentiary, as above set forth, and subsequently, to-wit, on the 14th of September, 1914, a hearing was accorded petitioner for the purpose of affording him an opportunity to show cause why he should not be deported under said warrant, and at said hearing petitioner failed to satisfy the immigration authorities of his United States citizenship, and is now -2-
being held for the purpose of verifying representations of citizenship made by petitioner at said hearing, in which statements he purported to give facts and data by which his United States citizenship could be established.

II. That on the 25th day of June, 1910, petitioner was given a hearing before the United States Immigration Commissioner at Seattle, Washington, under a charge that he was in the United States unlawfully, and for the purpose of affording him an opportunity to show cause why she should not be deported to the country from whence he came, and in the course of said hearing petitioner, being under oath to testify the truth, stated that he was born in Montreal, Canda, of French-Canadian parents, and resided in Montreal, Canada, fourteen years after his birth, and then went to the state of Louisiana in the United States of America; that he had never been naturalized and had not voted; that he always understood he was a citizen of the United States because his father had been naturalized; and that he was unable to swear that his father had been naturalized.

III. At a subsequent hearing before the Immigration Commissioner on June 29, 1910, petitioner, under oath, again stated that he was a native of Canda, having been born at Vercheres near Montreal, Canada, January 10, 1857; that he left Canada for the state of Louisiana, United States of America, in 1877.

IV. At a hearing before the United States Immigration -3-
Commissioner on September 14, 1914, petitioner, being under oath, swore he was born in the city of New Orleans, Louisiana.
V. The full original record of the hearings above referred to before the United States Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle, Washington, will be produced at the hearing of this case.
Wherefore respondent asks that the petition be denied and a writ of habeas corpus herein be discharged.
div1.ab: Henry M. White Commissioner of Immigration.
Albert Moodie Assistant United States Attorney.
div1.p: The United States of America, Western District of Washington, Northern Divison. }ss.
Henry M. White, being first duly sworn, upon his oath deposes and says:

That he is Commissioner of Immigration of the port of Seattle, Washington, and respondent herein; that he has read the foregoing return to the order to show cause, knows the contents thereof, and that the same is true as he verily believes.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 1st day of October, 1914.
div1.ab: Albert Moodie Notary Public referred State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
div1.p: In the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington Northern Division
In the Matter of the Petition of Arthur B. Martin for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Return
Filed in the U.S. District Court, Western Dist. of Washington OCT 16 1914 Frank L. Crosby, Clerk, By EML Deputy.
